questionText: The control management function ensures that ________ in an organization.
A major part of the controlling function of management is to ________.
The more a control system helps an organization ________, the more successful it is judged to be.
A well-run company that has well-thought-out plans, motivated and productive workers, and an efficient organizational structure ________.
multipleChoice: may not always attain its goals
has no reason to monitor its performance

questionText: The value of the controlling function is seen in three specific areas: planning, ________.
multipleChoice: protecting employees, and empowering the workplace
protecting employees, and protecting the workplace
empowering employees, and protecting the workplace

questionText: Controlling is the ________ in the management process.
Controlling compares ________ to see if goals are being achieved.
Effective controlling can help managers ________.
The controlling function helps managers protect an organization's ________.
The first step in the control process is to ________.
multipleChoice: compare a standard against an ideal

questionText: Managers always use these for performance standards during the control process.
multipleChoice: goals created during the planning process

questionText: A manager measuring actual performance is like a teacher ________.
multipleChoice: helping a student study for a test

questionText: ________ are the most informal form of performance measurement.
MBWA stands for management by ________.
An advantage of management by walking around is ________.
For a baseball player, a statistical report would feature such things as ________.
multipleChoice: a newspaper profile of the player

questionText: A disadvantage of a statistical report is that it may leave out ________ measurements of performance.
A(n) ________ format would be most likely to include graphs, tables, and computer outputs.
________ performance measurement method is fast and is a good platform for feedback, yet it can be private and scheduled for a single employee ahead of time.
Of the options given, the most comprehensive form of performance measurement is this.
Stefan has a recording of a one-on-one meeting with his boss. This represents ________.

Jesus' assigned work section consists of three work groups who were assessed by this method of performance measurement and were informally judged to be "creative, innovative, hard-working, and fun-loving."
The ________ forms of performance measurement provide the best and most immediate forms of feedback.
What managers choose to measure is largely determined by ________.
multipleChoice: what an organization wants to do well
the leaders and leadership style of those in the organization

questionText: A car company that puts more effort into measuring quality than total units sold most likely wants to excel at ________.

A software company that puts almost all of its performance measurement effort into measuring the total number of units that the company and its competitors sell most likely wants to excel at ________.
A state motor vehicles agency that is tasked with serving the public might choose to measure ________.
multipleChoice: total revenue rather than customer wait time
total customers rather than total revenue
customer wait time rather than total customers
employee turnover rather than customer wait time

questionText: Which one of the following performance measurement categories must be measured subjectively rather than in objective or quantifiable terms?
The second step in the control process is to ________.
multipleChoice: compare a standard against an ideal

questionText: To carry out the second step of the control process, managers at an electric shaver company need to compare the number of actual shavers sold to ________.
multipleChoice: the number of possible shaver customers

questionText: In the second step of the control process, actual performance can be considered acceptable as long as the performance doesn't fall ________.
multipleChoice: short of goals by more than 15 percent
short of goals by more than 30 percent
inside an acceptable range of variation
outside an acceptable range of variation

questionText: In general, ________ that falls outside an acceptable range of variation must be dealt with by a manager.
multipleChoice: a small overperformance or a large underperformance

questionText: The third step in the control process is to ________.
multipleChoice: compare a standard against an ideal

questionText: When actual performance falls outside an acceptable range of variation, it is termed a(n).
When should a manager's course of action be to do nothing?
multipleChoice: when the cause of the variation has been identified
when the standard is not acceptable

questionText: Actual performance falls short of planned goals, yet a manager takes no action. Assuming this manager is a reasonable person and is not mistaken, what is the most likely cause of his inaction?
multipleChoice: He does not trust the data.
He does not consider the deviation significant.
He does not trust the goals that were set.
He does not believe in corrective action.

questionText: Which one of the following is NOT a recognized possible course of action for managers to take when actual performance falls outside an acceptable range of variation?
If a manager of a tennis store sees sales totals for a particular racquet significantly exceeding goals and deviating from acceptable range of variation, she might ________.
multipleChoice: do nothing since sales exceeded goals
run a sale on the racquet
run a sale on other products

questionText: After an extended period of unseasonably warm and sunny weather, revenue at an indoor tennis club are down sharply during the month of November, but are in line with what managers expected for the month. The best strategy for the club manager is to ________.
multipleChoice: run a sale on hourly rates
raise hourly rates to increase revenue
change her monthly goals for December

questionText: 49) Due to recent construction of an upscale housing community near a tennis club, customer use has skyrocketed during the year and the club is operating at all-time high levels, far beyond the goals set the previous year. The best strategy for the manager is to ________.
multipleChoice: B) run a sale to increase customers
D) change goals for the following year

questionText: 50) Immediate corrective action is designed ________.
multipleChoice: A) to get to the root cause of a problem
B) to get performance back on track
C) to shake up an organization
D) to punish employees for poor performance

questionText: 51) For addressing the hardships accompanying unemployment, ________ is an example of immediate corrective action.
multipleChoice: B) temporary assistance to needy families
C) a task force to see why jobs were lost

questionText: 52) For addressing unemployment, ________ is an example of basic corrective action.
multipleChoice: A) a task force to see why jobs were lost

questionText: 53) In many cases, immediate corrective action rather than basic corrective action is taken by managers because the manager may ________.
54) Which one of the following would constitute basic corrective action for employees whose production has dropped?
multipleChoice: C) looking for causes of the production drop
D) changing how the work is carried out

questionText: 55) A law firm manager finds that one lawyer who consistently outperforms other lawyers at the firm is threatening to leave. Which immediate corrective action should the manager take?
multipleChoice: D) a study to see why she outperforms others

questionText: 56) A law firm manager finds that the firm loses too many of its civil cases while it wins an inordinately high number of its criminal cases. Which basic corrective action can the manager take?
multipleChoice: C) analyze civil and criminal cases

questionText: 57) When might a manager be justified in revising a standard rather than taking corrective action to remedy a significant performance deviation?
multipleChoice: A) when performance exceeds the standard
B) when performance falls slightly short of the standard
C) when performance falls far short of the standard
D) when the standard is unrealistic

questionText: 58) A professor gives a new test to an otherwise typical class and finds that only 10 percent of the students earn grades of C or above. What is the most appropriate and fair response?
multipleChoice: B) revise the grading curve downward
C) revise the grading curve upward

questionText: 59) All of the following are dangers of revising production goals downward EXCEPT ________.
multipleChoice: A) it destroys incentive to work harder
B) it increases incentive to work harder
C) it gives employees an excuse to be less productive
D) it gives employees something to blame for their lack of effort

questionText: 79) Which kind of control takes place before the actual work is carried out?
80) A cell phone maker tests its new model with a sample audience when it is fully operational. What kind of control is this?
81) Which kind of control takes place while the actual work is carried out?
82) Direct supervision of employees is a form of ________ control.

83) An action show producer has a read-through of a half-written show in which actors, writers, producers, and the director are free to make comments and changes before the show is filmed. What kind of control is being used?
84) A fast-food restaurant is querying prospective customers about the features they would like to see in a new panini sandwich. What kind of control is being used?
85) Which kind of control takes place after the actual work has been carried out?
86) A basketball coach showing players how to position themselves on the court during practice is carrying out ________, a form of concurrent control.
87) One advantage of feedback control over other forms of control is that it lets managers focus on ________.
multipleChoice: A) what is about to take place
B) how on target their planning efforts were
C) how effective their organizing efforts were
D) the task as it is being carried out

questionText: 88) When feedback control shows that planning goals and actual performance were dramatically different, the most likely conclusion is that ________.
multipleChoice: A) planning was not on target
D) goals do not need to be changed

questionText: 89) An advantage of feedback control is that it improves ________.
Managers exert financial control on an organization using ________ analysis.
________ is a measure of an organization's ability to meet its current debt obligations.
________ is a measure of an organization's ability to efficiently use its assets.
________ is a measure of an organization's use of debt to finance its assets.
________ is a measure of how readily a company can use its assets to generate profits.
A company looks at its expenses and finds that its payments to freelancers increased significantly over the past few months, exceeding the budget by 25 percent. This is an example of ________.
multipleChoice: using data to confirm a budget
using a budget for monitoring and controlling

questionText: A company looks at its expenses and finds that its payments to freelancers increased significantly over the past few months, exceeding the budget by 25 percent. Which one of the following is the most reasonable action for the company to take?
multipleChoice: fire the people who were responsible for the expenses
ignore the expenses as an aberration
see what the expenses were for

questionText: A company looks at its expenses and finds that its electricity costs have increased, exceeding the budget by 20 percent. If true, which one of the following would be most likely to require immediate action on the part of the company?
multipleChoice: The price per kilowatt hour for electricity has gone up by 25 percent.
The price per kilowatt hour has gone up by 15 percent.
The price per kilowatt hour for electricity has gone down by five percent.
The price per kilowatt hour has stayed steady.

questionText: When a budget is formulated, it is being used as a(n) ________ tool.
When a budget is used for controlling, it provides ________ against which resource consumption can be compared.
A household that cuts back on supermarket spending after going over budget on its food expenses is using the budget as a(n) ________.
A family that is using a computer program to create a formal household budget is using the budget as a(n) ________.
A management information system (MIS) provides managers with ________ data.
All of the following are important in efforts to protect information in an organization EXCEPT ________.
A balanced scorecard approach creates goals in four key performance areas and assesses ________.
multipleChoice: whether the majority of them are met
whether all four goals are met
whether financial goals exceed the other goals

questionText: In which country would highly centralized decision making be more likely to be prevalent?
Direct supervision as a basic means of control is much more common in ________.
When comparing Mexico to Scotland, you would expect Scottish workers to have ________.
Which statement about employee privacy is correct?
multipleChoice: Employers have a legal right to monitor on-the-job employee phone calls.
Employers have no legal right to monitor on-the-job employee phone calls.
Employers have the legal right to monitor all employee phone calls.
Employers do not have the right to monitor any employee phone calls.

questionText: Which one of the following employer practices is NOT legal?
multipleChoice: tracking an employee's whereabouts in the workplace
monitoring an employee's personal home computer

questionText: Of the following choices, ________ is the most common reason for companies firing employees.
Monitoring ________ has proved to be very helpful in establishing culpability in sexual harassment cases.
What fraction of U.S. employees do personal website surfing every day?
Annual losses from organizational theft and fraud amount to about ________ per worker.
An effective feedforward strategy for dealing with employee theft is ________.
multipleChoice: screen workers before they are hired
openly state the real costs of stealing

questionText: An effective concurrent strategy for dealing with employee theft of supplies and equipment is ________.
All of the following are common rationalizations that workers use to justify workplace theft EXCEPT ________.
In any given week, at least ________ workers are attacked by coworkers or former coworkers and seriously injured in the United States.
Workplace violence is most likely to occur in ________.
multipleChoice: both functional or dysfunctional workplacesâ€”violence shows no pattern
